newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES EDGE UP DESPITE LIQUIDITY.
newsitem.headline: ZIMBABWE MONEY RATES EDGE UP DESPITE LIQUIDITY.

text.p: Short-term trading rates on Zimbabwe's money market were quoted largely firmer despite a surplus of cash in the system on Friday, dealers said.
The market opened with an unsettled surplus of 137.8 million and further liquidity was added on maturity of Z$400 million worth of treasury bills.
But the central Reserve Bank only managed to mop up Z$235 million by auctioning 91-day treasury bills with an average yield of 23.36 percent.
Treasury bills were being traded on the secondary market at 22 percent, down from 22.75 percent, but call money, also quoted at 22 percent, added two percentage points.

NCD bills maturing after 30, 60 and 90 days were quoted at 25.5 and 23.75 percent (buying and selling respectively) from 25 and 22 percent. Bank acceptances were being bought at 24.5 percent from 24.25 but sold unchanged at 23 percent.
